items.title: Funeral for world-renowned conservationist Jane Goodall
items.summary_auto: A private funeral is being held at the Washington National Cathedral today for Jane Goodall, who died on Oct. 1 at the age of 91, but the public is being invited to watch via livestream.

items.title: Refugee claims jump 98% in Sask. as immigration cuts leave newcomers in limbo
items.summary_auto: Refugee claims in Saskatchewan have surged by almost 98 per cent since major federal and provincial immigration cuts came into effect, according to Statistics Canada. Saskatchewan also saw the country's steepest drop in permanent residents, but is expected to get around 1,000 more provincial nominee spots next year.

items.title: 20 Turkish troops killed in military plane crash in Georgia
items.summary_auto: Turkey's defence ministry said on Wednesday that 20 soldiers were killed in the crash of its military aircraft in Georgia a day earlier, as inspectors continued to seek clues what caused the NATO member's cargo plane to go down.

items.title: Federal investigation probes grocery store competition in Halifax
items.summary_auto: Since last year, an investigation into the ability of new grocers to set up in the Halifax Regional Municipality has been quietly ticking along under Competition Bureau Canada.

items.title: P.E.I'.s oyster industry looking south of the border for help battling deadly diseases
items.summary_auto: A P.E.I. company is seeking approval to import disease-resistant oyster seed and broodstock from the United States. Some Island oyster growers support the idea, but many in the wild oyster industry do not.

items.title: Peninsular Halifax doesn't have a French high school. Will that change?
items.summary_auto: Last week, the head of Nova Scotia's francophone school board said that rural geography is keeping some students from getting a French education. In the Halifax area, lengthy commutes due to traffic are keeping some students from getting a French high school education.

items.title: P.E.I. company seeks approval to import disease-resistant oyster stock from the U.S.
items.summary_auto: A P.E.I. company is seeking approval to import disease-resistant oyster seed and broodstock from the United States. Some Island oyster growers support the idea, but many in the wild oyster industry do not.

items.title: Swedish king’s visit highlights growing Canadian interest in Saab military aircraft
items.summary_auto: A few days before the federal budget was tabled, the CEO of Swedish industrial giant Saab flew to Ottawa to meet with the country's top bureaucrat, fuelling the sense a deal is brewing between the Canadian government and the military manufacturer. Now, the country's king, queen and a delegation of political and business leaders are set to visit from Nov. 18-20.

items.title: Renowned exoplanet researcher Sara Seager is bringing her quest to find another Earth back home to Canada
items.summary_auto: Canadian astronomical research is getting a big boost with the return of Sara Seager to Canada after around 20 years at MIT. Her research includes looking for life in the clouds of Venus and searching for Earth 2.0.

items.title: How climate change is threatening the future of winter sport
items.summary_auto: Glacial melt has halted summer skiing on the Horstman Glacier at Whistler Blackcomb, a crucial spot for national team athletes and young skiers looking to train with the pros. An Olympian has an idea to bring summer skiing back to the glacier, but it could be years away and won't come cheap.

items.title: Front-line police patrol in Windsor sometimes at 'dangerously low' levels, says union
items.summary_auto: The Windsor Police Association (WPA) is pushing for mandatory minimums on the front lines after a recent patrol shift dropped to what they describe as concerning levels.

items.title: U.S. tourism faces $5.7B US loss as Canadians continue to stay home
items.summary_auto: Many Canadians continue to boycott travel to the United States, and the U.S. economy is paying the price. A U.S. Travel Association report forecasts a 3.2 per cent decline in international tourism spending in the country for 2025, a loss of $5.7 billion US compared to the previous year.

items.title: Montreal transit strike over as maintenance workers' union suspends work stoppage
items.summary_auto: A day before Quebec's labour minister is set to table a bill that would give the provincial government the power to end the ongoing public transit strike, the union representing maintenance workers with Montreal's public transit authority announced it was suspending its month-long strike.

items.title: Ottawa tinkers with veterans' disability benefits as former soldiers prepare for a fight
items.summary_auto: The federal budget proposes to change how veterans' disability pensions are indexed — something advocates say could cost individuals thousands of dollars in lost income.

items.title: B.C. MMA champion denounces gyms, coaches with ties to white supremacist groups
items.summary_auto: An MMA champion and Olympian is speaking out against hate and racism after a CBC investigation found that certain martial arts gym owners, coaches and trainers were among the attendees of a  secretive neo-Nazi conference in Vancouver over the summer.

items.title: Israeli settlers attack 2 occupied West Bank villages as violence against Palestinians surges
items.summary_auto: Masked Israeli settlers hurled stones and torched dairy trucks, farmland and Bedouin structures, injuring four people on Tuesday in the latest in a surge of settler attacks in the occupied West Bank.

items.title: Durham regional police's 'poisoned' workplace highlighted in Ontario Civilian Police Commission report
Vancouver woman found dead in Belize after stabbing, authorities confirm
items.summary_auto: A Vancouver woman was found dead at a spa in Belize on Monday after a stabbing, local police have confirmed.

items.title: Keep your eyes on the skies across Canada, and you just might see the northern lights
items.summary_auto: Skygazers are spotting the lights deeper into Canada, the U.S. and Europe because the sun is going through a major facelift. Every 11 years, its poles swap places, causing magnetic twists and tangles along the way.

items.title: Severe solar storm could trigger auroras across Canada and northern U.S. states
items.summary_auto: Skygazers are spotting the lights deeper into Canada, the U.S. and Europe because the sun is going through a major facelift. Every 11 years, its poles swap places, causing magnetic twists and tangles along the way.

items.title: Why Trump threatened to sue the BBC for $1B US | About That
items.summary_auto: U.S. President Donald Trump has threatened legal action against the BBC for its editing of a speech he gave on Jan. 6, 2021 — the day his supporters overran the Capitol — in the broadcaster's flagship Panorama documentary program. The British broadcaster admitted to an 'error of judgment,' prompting two of its senior leaders to resign. Andrew Chang breaks down how all this happened, and why the network may have to pay a steep price to defend its reputation.

items.title: Pride flags, fluoride, abortion: Here's what UCP will push Danielle Smith to change next
Sally Kirkland, stage-screen actress and Oscar nominee for Anna, dead at 84
items.summary_auto: American model-turned-actress Sally Kirkland, who was noted for her stage, TV and film roles — including sharing the screen with Paul Newman and Robert Redford in The Sting and earning an Oscar nomination for 1987's Anna — has died at 84.

items.title: A young Calgarian was a top flying ace for Canada — and later, the namesake for a prominent boulevard
items.summary_auto: Willie McKnight, an ace pilot from Alberta, joined the Royal Air Force in 1939 and became a highly decorated fighter pilot during the Second World War. Local historian Shelly McElroy joined the Calgary Eyeopener on Remembrance Day to reflect on the namesake of the city's McKnight Boulevard.

items.title: Hurricane Melissa death toll rises to 45 in Jamaica, with 15 others still missing
items.summary_auto: The number of confirmed deaths from Hurricane Melissa in Jamaica rose to 45, with 15 other people missing, authorities said Tuesday. The death toll is expected to rise, with officials still trying to reach two towns that remain cut off since the catastrophic Category 5 storm made landfall in western Jamaica on Oct. 28.
